Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RUI---Integrated Inventory of Biomes of the Arctic
Award.AbstractNarration:
This museum-based study of northern biological diversity will link academic, state and federal institutions, and will result in an integrated biological inventory of high-latitude plants, mammals and associated parasites in Siberia, Alaska and Canada. A focus on poorly known regions in the Arctic and subarctic will build a comprehensive picture of biotic structure, evolution, and ecology, establishing a foundation for detecting and predicting responses to accelerated environmental change. Specimens and biological information will be made available via globally accessible databases, providing a pathway to assess the history, relationships and distribution of inter-hemispheric diversity. Cutting-edge molecular tools applied to new collections of plant, mammal, and parasite specimens will allow investigators and students to determine the sequence, age, location, and consequences of major climatic events that structured northern biodiversity.

Broader impacts emerge from the availability of specimens for studies of zoonotic diseases and conservation genetics. The project will provide training and experience for US students participating in highly productive international collaborations in Russia, Finland and Canada. Infrastructure in the US will be strengthened by augmenting museum collection resources, which will be available to scientists and educators for study as they tackle emerging challenges for science and society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Integrated Investigations of Biomes of the Arctic (CIIBA) was a field, museum, and molecular laboratory study of mammals, their associated parasites, and plants of northern latitudes. We emphasized building key scientific infrastructure (especially museum collections and related databases) for future integrated specimen-based studies into how ancient and current environmental change has shaped northern ecosystems. The new specimens and data acquired through CIIBA include thousands of individual mammals, parasites, and plants representing hundreds of species and dozens of localities spanning transects encompassing thousands of kilometers across Asia (Mongolia, Siberia, and Japan), North America, and Greenland.

 

These specimens provide a necessary foundation for understanding processes of community assembly and persistence, species limits, and diversification across the Holarctic region, with a focus on Beringia, the historical land bridge that periodically linked Asia to North America during glacial periods of the Pleistocene. The specimens also establish a biodiversity baseline that will be critical for revealing the impacts of accelerated ecological disturbance across the North.  As high-latitude ecosystems are increasingly disrupted by changing environments and industrial development, this record will allow us to document how species respond to these changes.  Without specimen baselines, the consequences of environmental change for species and communities will be lost to history.  In addition, the CIIBA record provides a foundation for comparative analyses that can document the effects of dynamic change on the geographic distribution, transmission dynamics, and emergence of pathogens.  For example, in our work on mammals we have studied carnivores, shrews, lagomorphs, ungulates and rodents and their associated parasites to demonstrate how this new infrastructure informs science and policy. 

 

All specimens collected through CIIBA are archived in museum collections with publicly accessible databases.  Mammals and parasites are primarily archived in the Museum of Southwestern Biology at the University of New Mexico, with some at the Northern Michigan University Museum of Zoology (both collection databases are searchable at arctos.database.museum).  Plants are archived at the Western Washington University Herbarium (WWB; searchable via pnwherbaria.org).  Specimens, which were collected and preserved using techniques designed to maximize the utility of the material for an array of downstream analytical methods (e.g., morphometrics, DNA sequencing, isotope analysis), are available for loan to members of the scientific community.  This specimen resource has already contributed to more than 50 peer-reviewed publications and several graduate theses, which have investigated an array of basic and applied research topics, including 1) new species discovery, 2) predictive geographic modeling for rare and endemic plants, 3) characterizing host associations and geographic distributions for parasites and pathogens, 4) quantifying consequences of environmental change for parasite demography and pathogenicity, 5) quantifying effects of changing wildfire regimes on plant distributions, and 6) reconstructing phylogenetic and biogeographic histories for plants, mammals, and parasites. Technological advances will continue to open new pathways for extracting information from these permanent samples, which will increase their value and open the door to new research questions that we cannot today envision.  New applications of increasingly powerful approaches to genomics and stable isotope chemistry can extract novel information from museum specimens that were collected long before such tools were invented, underscoring the value of these irreplaceable archives.

 

In addition to our success in achieving the primary research goals of the project, CIIBA made strong contributions in terms of broader educational impacts via student training, community engagement, and development of educational modules.  Roughly 70 undergraduate students, 20 MS students, and 10 PhD students participated in aspects of the work and received intensive extracurricular training in field, museum, and/or laboratory methods for mammalogy, parasitology, or botany.  More than half of these students belonged to groups that are traditionally underrepresented in the sciences, including women and minorities. Students who participated in major CIIBA field expeditions cited their experience as being personally transformative, providing new clarity on life-goals and career aspirations. Further, we shared the results of our work with diverse and widespread audiences, presenting more than two dozen public lectures addressing aspects of the research.  The audiences for these lectures ranged from tribal high schools to campus and community organizations to wildlife managers and scientists at professional meetings. New educational modules based on these specimens were developed and are feely available online.

 

Finally, we built strong, new partnerships with scientists, students, and indigenous communities across Russia, Japan, Canada, Greenland, and Mongolia. For example, our collaboration with scientists from the National University of Mongolia is helping to illuminate Mongolia's natural heritage, and will undoubtedly influence decisions regarding conservation, wildlife management policy, and natural resource development.  We trained several Mongolian students in field methods, brought colleagues and two Mongolian students to the US to work in the collections, and established a foundation for developing future collaborative field-based experiences that bring American and Mongolian students together.  CIIBA provides a model for international cooperation with potential long-term impacts that reach far beyond the scope of our primary research.
